11:21 am
BE

Natixis incoming .....

BE

Will she, won’t she? In the end, Janet Yellen stayed put on the fence (no 25bp hike in the Fed Funds rate as the Federal Reserve passed its turn once again). This came as no great surprise to the market (there was only a 22% probability the Federal Reserve would move yesterday).
In all likelihood, the main obstacle was probably concern at catching the market by surprise and triggering a spike in volatility for all asset classes. But for this, and as pointed out by FMOC member Stanley Fischer, all indicators are on green: growth is at its potential, the economy is at full employment, the core CPI (excluding energy) at +2.3%, so above the official target, and markets are calm, China less a worry, Brexit too far away to be concerned with and volatility holding on low.
Clearly, the FOMC Statement wants to prepare the market for an interest rate hike... if all goes well, with a new phrase inserted in the FOMC Statement, following the speech by Janet Yellen at Jackson Hole, strengthening the probability of an interest rate hike:
“The Committee judges that the case for an increase in the federal funds rate has strengthened but decided, for the time being, to wait for further evidence of continued progress toward its objectives.”
Especially, three voting members (Esther George, Loretta Mester and Eric Rosengreen) signalled their disagreement, voting to raise the target range for the federal funds rate. This was the most flagrant show of dissent since December 2014.
The FOMC also revised its growth projection from 2% to 1.8% for this year and its PCE inflation projection from 1.4% to 1.3% for 2016, but still expects to reach 2% in 2018.

BE

Moreover the dot plot indicates that FMOC members still expect a monetary tightening this year, as near-term risks to the economic outlook appear roughly balanced and the labour market is improving further. Per the FOMC’s median predictions, the Fed Funds rate is still to be raised once this year and twice in 2016 (twice and three times, respectively, per dot plot for the June FOMC meeting).
Another change is that the longer run level of the Fed Funds rate has been lowered once again, from 3% to 2.9% (it was 3.25% before June).

11:21 am
BE

Clearly the Fed is playing the same tune as in 2015:several rate hikes announced, a window to trigger in September to eventually have a single move in December. At the start of the year, the dot plot indicated that FOMC members expected four interest rate hikes this year. Back in June, the FOMC’s median prediction was that there would be two further interest rate hikes this year, which clearly won’t happen.
Next month, the FOMC will meet on 1 and 2 November, just six days before US voters go the polls to elect Donald Trump or Hillary Clinton.
Many believe that the Federal Reserve will not come off the fence in November, even though in the past the central bank has raised the Fed Funds rate in the run-up to a presidential election.
At the same time, maybe this would go largely unnoticed six days before what promises to be the most important post-war presidential election.
In our view the Fed should hike in December which is still clearly our Central scenario, when new growth predictions will be published and there will be a press conference.
At the start of the year, the dot plot indicated that FOMC members expected four interest rate hikes this year. Back in June, the FOMC’s median prediction was that there would be two further interest rate hikes this year, which clearly won’t happen.Before the meeting, the market priced in just two interest rate hikes,,, but by the start of 2019.
If the Federal Reserve plans on raising the Fed Funds rate only when the market is ready, rather more plain talking will be needed. Janet Yellen must not tread in the footsteps of Alan Greenspan, who famously said “I guess I should warn you, if I turn out to be particularly clear, you’ve probably misunderstood what I said”. Nothing is certain in this respect.

BE

Here's the chart plot of the dot plot.

BE

If you get my gist.

PM

11:23 am
PM

Three dissents, two meetings left this year, one hike in the cards
The Fed followed the path of least resistance in September: they set the table for a
December move while projecting a shallower path for hikes thereafter. The statement
kept the focus on a December tightening, saying that they were waiting "for the time
being", that risks are "roughly balanced”, and there were three dissents in favor of
tightening. FOMC participants now project just one hike this year (consistent with our
economists’ call for a December hike), and in today’s projections the FOMC also revised
lower its forecasts for end-2017 and end-2018 each by 50bp relative to June forecasts.

BE

(@Roddy: behave.)

PM

Markets were ready for a “hawkish pass” and got something more dovish
With markets priced around 60% for a Dec hike pre-meeting, the bar for a hawkish
surprise was high, and the shifts in the longer-term forecasts probably made it
marginally dovish relative to market expectations. On the margin, the outcome is
bearish the USD, supportive of long-term bonds, and good for risk assets and the
search for carry. There are still three months until the December meeting, which should
limit market pricing for that meeting from nearing 100% anytime soon. At the same
time, the Fed will remain eager to retain optionality and prevent pricing from dipping
far below 50%.

11:23 am
PM

The dollar is unlikely to be rewarded
Even with the focus on a December hike, we do not expect the USD to be rewarded
against DM currencies. We have long argued that policy divergence by itself is not
sufficient to support another USD rally, unless it is accompanied by favourable growth
differentials (see Global FX Atlas: "Why won't yields steer the dollar?"). With the US
likely to post another year of modest growth, we do not expect the divergence that
would be necessary to trigger a significant USD rally. Recent price action is consistent
with this. Pricing for a December hike has risen from near zero in July to above 50%
currently, yet the dollar has actually weakened over this period. We continue to think
the dollar has peaked on a trade-weighted basis versus DM currencies, the euro in
particular, and we continue to forecast a rise in EUR/USD toward 1.16 by year end.

PM

Back-end yields likely to remain low, supporting risk and carry
The Treasury curve bull flattened after the FOMC statement, with 10-year yields falling
4bp. We think the impact on the long-end is appropriate and expect this to persist. US
data is improving relative to H1, yet bond yields are unlikely to rise significantly,
especially given low rates globally, low equilibrium real rates, and soft inflation
dynamics. Risk should remain supported and low yields should extend the search for
carry. In a recent publication, we explored how and why low yields are critical for equity
valuations in the current regime (see "Big Macro 04: Secular stagnation and equities;
the new normal"). We also continue to favour 30-year TIPS, as the market prices in
stubbornly high real rates and near historically-low medium-term breakevens.

PM

Signposts: employment, financial conditions, and inflation expectations
The labor market will be key to a December hike, and there are still three more
employment reports before the December meeting. Growth matters too, and in
particular the Q3 GDP report (October 28th), where our economists expect a rebound
relative to H1. Inflation expectations are important as well, and indeed Chair Yellen
acknowledged today that longer-term measures have shown some "slippage". Fed
hawkishness in the face of modest growth and below-target inflation has likely
weighed on inflation expectations. Finally, there has been an important feedback loop
between the Fed and financial conditions, with easier financial conditions driven by
higher equity prices tending to make them more hawkish, and vice versa. This will be
an important dynamic to watch as we approach the next hike.

11:29 am
BE

The changes in Chinese government policy this year have clearly been effective. Now even domestic coal producers prefer to use swing supply at certain price levels, rather than see the new 276 working day rule relaxed. Unless there are future import restrictions, we would expect the price arbitrage to keep seaborne thermal coal prices range bound between $50/t-$70/t and increase our long term price forecast to $60/t (prev $50/t). The impact upgrades our Glencore NPV by 37p to 230p and our rating to HOLD.

BE

nadvertent beneficiary

Glencore benefits in the long term from these policy changes. They not only raise coal prices, but also make Chinese coal miners even less cost competitive by dropping productivity.

165mtpa of swing supply

New rules allow up to 165mtpa of domestic swing capacity which imply price downside from spot, however this already reflected in share prices with spot FCF yield of 17%.

Sustainable because of size

As the domestic industry is 4x the seaborne coal market it could feasibly match the falls in both domestic consumption and seaborne demand, even with India peaking.

NPV upgrade of 37p

Raising LT thermal coal prices to $60/t we upgrade our Glencore NPV to 230p and rating to HOLD. Our price target of 185p is based on 0.8x multiple of NPV.

BE

Inadvertent beneficiary

Glencore benefits in the long term from these policy changes. They not only raise coal prices, but also make Chinese coal miners even less cost competitive by dropping productivity.

165mtpa of swing supply

New rules allow up to 165mtpa of domestic swing capacity which imply price downside from spot, however this already reflected in share prices with spot FCF yield of 17%.

Sustainable because of size

As the domestic industry is 4x the seaborne coal market it could feasibly match the falls in both domestic consumption and seaborne demand, even with India peaking.

Rocket Internet (Sell): 1H16#s. More questions than answers

11:35 am
PM

Within the 1H16 Rocket numbers this morning our attention is drawn to three concerns. Namely the LPV calculation, the disappearance of financials for a key business (Delivery Hero) and the sharp growth slowdown for the largest (Hello Fresh).

Rocket Internet’s KPI, Last Portfolio Value, has been updated to September 15, 2016. However, we are struggling to reconcile the numbers. Rocket’s LPV is E5.12B on their disclosed valuations. This compares to E5.33B at the end of April 2016 and E5.96B at the
end of March 2016. Given this includes the down rounds in financing for both GFG and Home24 this would appear to be a reasonable performance against a tough market (See CBInsights stats below). However, closer inspection on the LPV raises concerns for us once
again.

PM

Since the LPV at the end of April, which carried the GFG value reduction, Rocket related companies Home24 and Delivery Hero have had capital raising (Delivery Hero) or carried value reductions in co-investor reports (e.g. Home24). The Home 24 capital raising
this month has reduced Rocket’s stake to E180M from E440M. But for Delivery Hero, there has still been no financial disclosure on the valuation at the time of the high two-digit million Euro capital raise (announced 18th August). Yet the LPV on Delivery Hero
(in which Rocket has a 37.3% stake) is still based off a last financing round from December 2015. Rocket calculate Delivery Hero to be worth E2.89B with a value to Rocket’s LPV of E1.08B. It remains the second largest contribution to Rocket’s LPV. So why is
there no update to the LPV contribution in nine months and post a capital raising? It also begs a further question for us.

PM

Why are Delivery Hero financials missing from the 1H 2016 statement this morning?

Even the appendix to the statement shows the businesses of Hello Fresh, Foodpanda, GFG top-level financials but Delivery Hero appears to be totally missing, having vanished into thin air. And there is no mention of Delivery Hero in the presentation to accompany
the results. Yet the company is focused on increasing transparency?

11:35 am
PM

Neil's furious, yeah?

PM

The 1H16 statement appears to us to have the proverbial “more holes than Swiss cheese”.

And the largest single contributor to Rocket LPV, Hello Fresh, appears to be showing a sharp deceleration in growth. It would appear that the focus on improving profitability (or rather, less losses) is dragging on growth with 2Q16 net revenues of E150.1M (on
adjusted EBITDA margin of -12.3%) growing just 6% from E141.6M (on adjusted EBITDA margin of -19.3%) reported in 1Q16.

PM

As well he might, being short a stock that's popped 11 per cent

11:36 am
PM

We made adjustments to our estimates of Rocket companies LPVs at the beginning of September in light of Unicorn down-rounds, business challenges and co-investor mark to market transactions. Relative to Rocket’s owned carried valuations we reduced Hello Fresh,
Delivery Hero, Jumia and Linio carried valuations by 30%, reduced Food Panda carried valuation by 50% owing to tough trading conditions and adjusted West Wing and Home 24 on a mark-to-market basis in line with co-investor Kinnevik valuations. We also reduced
the fair value of the new business and investment by 25% to reflect the more challenging conditions of companies Easy Taxi (exiting Asia and Africa) and the Latin American Internet Group, which has a stake in GFG. We don’t feel these actions are overly aggressive
given VC backed private technology company valuations have fallen by an average of 30-50% in 2016 (Source: CBInsights). The result of these actions produces a current Rocket group LPV of EUR3.59B, which is still 30% below the EUR5.12B Group LPV Rocket has
reported this morning).

With weak business momentum, opaque funding structures, concerns over the ability for portfolio companies to scale profitably and the ongoing risk of down rounds in portfolio companies we remain sellers of Rocket Internet.

PM

Hold your nerve, Campling

PM

Just hold on

BE

Rocket Internet (N) published its H1 16 results after having released a better
than expected performance for GFG last week. Weighted average H1 16
revenues were up +32% YoY for Selected Portfolio companies and EBITDA
margin improved by 15ppts YoY to -17%. As a reminder, Q1 16 revenues
were up +34%, though this included Linio which saw a -51% decline (the
company has not included Linio in H1 results). EBITDA margins of Proven
Winners showed an improvement both YoY in H1 15 and compared to Q1 15
(-22% margin, though again it included Linio), which we view positively.
Most companies’ revenues were broadly as expected, and adj. EBITDA losses
a touch better. Jumia was below our expectations, which on the revenue side is
due partly to a faster shift to the marketplace model. The company has
completed €164m of (nominal) convertible bond repurchases, and may spend
a further €85m on repurchases up to 30 Sep 2017. Importantly, the company
has reiterated its guidance for at least three portfolio companies to turn
profitable by end 2017.

PM

ML back end clearly celebrating the fact

BE

Here's Exane downgrading to neutral.

BE

After last year’s shock profit warning, Pearson has needed to deliver on expectations to rebuild confidence. However, the US higher education courseware market looks weaker than expected despite signs of an improvement in enrolment over the summer. This raises the risk of a further setback at the Q3 results. We fear more turbulence ahead and cut to Neutral.

Downgrading to Neutral

We downgrade Pearson to Neutral with a new TP of 900p. We have reduced our EPS16e by 6% and EPS17e by 5% and are concerned consensus might have to revise 2016 forecasts down post Q3 results. We believe another setback is likely to weigh on the share price until H2 17.

US higher education courseware market looks weaker than expected...

July and August are the key selling months for US higher education courseware publishers. Wiley pointed to a weak market in July. Our industry contacts suggest August was below expectations too. We believe this weakness was largely caused by destocking at bookstores. We doubt market share gains will be enough to offset industry weakness.

11:48 am
BE

Wasn't that much of a "shock" profit warning, TBH ......

BE

...despite signs of an improvement in enrolment

The weakness is all the more surprising as there is anecdotal evidence that college enrolment is improving in the US. Enrolments are up 1% in our tracking sample. There are much fewer negative enrolment articles on Google News than last year; the freshman count at University of California is up for the first time in four years. This is likely to raise doubt on the cyclical recovery argument.

Better entry points to play an expected 2017 turnaround

We continue to anticipate an organic revenue growth recovery next year. The stock remains on sector and peer group relative lows and offers a sustainable dividend yield of 6.6%. But we have concerns on 2016 trends and believe there might be better entry points to play the expected 2017 turnaround later next year. We see more compelling ideas elsewhere in Media.

BE

With a market cap of some $9m less than its cash and a conservative management team ensuring that few if any risks are taken in this ‘lower for longer’ environment then what can go wrong? Chariot’s survival instincts are laudable and they have some seriously high beta prospects still in the portfolio to drill if and when they become economically sound and when cash is freer, in the meantime it looks like just three wells to look forward to in the next two years. This includes the exciting RD-1 well where they are carried by Eni offshore Morocco and capped just to ensure no comeback of any sort. So, not much can go wrong and there are some faint signs of excitement in what is an interesting if mainly dormant portfolio, conservative is good but doesnt always make for returns which are clearly quite a long way down the road.

BE

That was Malcy, who you can read here: http://www.malcysblog.com/

undefined
11:54 am
BE

Further up the market, big Jefferies note on the utils.

BE

Downgrading Drax. It's the usual stuff about uncertainty over CfDs and biomass subsidies.

BE

Following severe under-performance in 2015, Drax's share price has risen 50%
in 2016. However we expect this outperformance to unwind due to headwinds
in the UK power market. We see c.10% downside to current UK forward power
prices due to: (i) growing renewables and interconnection capacity; (ii) weak
demand; and (iii) a lower UK gas price. We downgrade Drax to Underperform
(from Hold) with a target price of 240p.

11:55 am
BE

Power price downside not priced in. Drax's earnings and valuation remains sensitive to
movements in UK power prices. We see downside to UK power prices which is not currently
reflected in Drax's share price. We expect power prices to fall to £34/MWh by 2018, versus
the current forward price of £38/MWh. A +£1/MWh move in Drax's achieved power price
is +11% on 2017 EBITDA.
CfD and positive capacity market result priced in. Whilst capacity market revenues
will bolster Drax's earnings from 2017, we believe higher clearing prices are expected and
well reflected in valuations. We assume a £20/KW clearing price for the January 2017 T-1
auction and £35/KW for the December 2016 T-4 auction. Near term upside could come from
a higher price in the T-1 auction. A +£5/KW clearing price would raise 2017 EBITDA by 5%.
Biomass cost risks move closer. Following the recent appreciation of the US dollar, risks
related to future biomass costs have risen. Management highlighted that post 2020, Drax's
biomass costs would be subject to movements in exchange rates. This is set to be a key risk
going forward given the sensitivity of Drax's earnings to fuel input prices.
Higher quality earnings not enough. Drax's earnings are set to become increasingly
visible. A positive EU state aid decision regarding the CfD contract for the third biomass
conversion is the biggest driver, but capacity market revenues and ancillary service contracts
will add to earnings visibility. Despite this we believe headwinds in power generation will
outweigh the increased certainty.
Recent outperformance and risks to consensus. As UK power prices recovered
through H1 2016, Drax outperformed significantly, rising 50% YTD, vs +18% for FTSE. We
believe current consensus ests reflect a recovery in UK power prices by 2018. Our bearish
assumptions leave us 30% below 2018 EBITDA consensus.
Valuation/Risks
We rate Drax with a Underperform recommendation and a 240p price target. Our PT
assumes Drax gains EU CfD approval at £100/MWh. Risks include; (1) EU CfD decision, (2) movement in commodity prices (3) rising biomass costs.

BE

Otherwise in the sector ......

BE

Centrica (Underperform, PT 190p): We downgrade Centrica to Underperform as we
believe that domestic energy supply and gas price headwinds are not fully reflected in the
current share price. We see the share price decoupling from the gas price with the UK energy supply now being the predominant driver of both earnings and valuation. At our PT Centrica trades on 12x 2017 PE with a 6.5% dividend yield. We see these multiples fairly reflecting upcoming headwinds.

BE

The retail squeeze. Falling commodity prices, evolving regulation and heightened
consumer awareness will continue to benefit independent suppliers in the UK domestic
energy supply market. By 2019, we expect Big Six supply profits to drop by 22% reflecting
an 11% market share loss and an 80 bps margin squeeze. Centrica, being the dominant
supplier, will be hit the hardest.
Lower power prices. We see c.10% downside to current UK forward power prices
due to: (i) growing renewables and interconnection capacity; (ii) weak demand; and (iii)
lower gas price. We see 15% downside to forward gas prices due to growing global LNG
export capacity, weak demand and increasing competition between traditional pipeline gas
suppliers and LNG exports.

Gulf Keystone (GKP LN – 2.15p) – Restructuring Dominates: Today’s results, on the face of them point towards a more positive future of the Company once it’s been able to restructure its balance sheet, given the $30mm net cash generation for the period. Of course this excludes approximately the same in bond coupon payments, which is why we think it underlines the need for this balance sheet restructuring. Invariably the equity holders will be significantly diluted, but they will have some measure of value, and provided that an opportunistic acquirer does not subsequently make a bid for the Company, which is a real and significant risk now that the balance sheet has been restored, then, once oil prices recover to “more normal levels,” we would expect the full value of Shaikan to be better reflective in the then share price, which will be significantly above the settled market price post restructuring. While investors will not be happy currently, the silver lining to this restructuring cloud is the fact that operationally the Company will be able to meet not only its ongoing costs but with the Company generating $30mm of free revenues, it should also be able to fund its forward programme, albeit to a limited extent.
